page.title: Survey
page.question: People are very optimistic about the organisation’s future.
There is high trust in Executive Management.
There is high trust in Middle Management.
There is a strong sense of success and achievement - ‘Things are getting better all the time’.
People are very positive about tackling problems. There is a ‘Can do’ mentality.
Change in the organisation = Better things to come for me.
There is a strong sense of purpose and direction.
People want to improve the way things work in the organisation.
There is a climate of ‘Trust and Respect’ throughout the organisation.
People are proud of the successes and achievements of the organisation.
What are the 3 most important things that you expect from the organisation?
What are the 3 most important things that you expect from the organisation?
What are the 3 most important things that you expect from the organisation?
How much do you agree that the organisation consistently meets your expectations?
How much do you agree that the organisation consistently meets your expectations?
How much do you agree that the organisation consistently meets your expectations?
Adequate flexibility in the hours/shifts you work.
Workloads that are fair and equitable.
A fair day’s pay for a fair day’s work.
Appropriate remuneration for the responsibilities you have.
The organisation provides … Recognition of my achievements.
The organisation provides … A friendly work environment.
The organisation provides … Good career opportunities.
The organisation provides … Opportunities for personal/professional development.
The organisation provides … Clear communication about things that affect me.
The organisation provides … The support I need to get the work done.
The organisation provides … Good physical conditions of employment.
A safe working environment for you.
The organisation provides … Secure employment.
What are 3 things (if any) that currently frustrate you the most in your day-to-day work?
What are 3 things (if any) that currently frustrate you the most in your day-to-day work?
What are 3 things (if any) that currently frustrate you the most in your day-to-day work?
... Being in control of many of my work choices.
... Being competent to do my role.
... Being optimistic about my future.
... Being useful to others.
... Making a difference in my chosen field.
... Being valued by others.
... Being a valued member of a team.
... Being treated with respect.
... Being treated as an individual, not just a number.
... Being included by others around me.
... Being included in decisions and discussions that affect me.
... Feeling safe at work to be the person I am.
... Feeling safe at work to “speak up” when required.
... Being supported to do my best.
... Being supported in learning from my mistakes.
... Being supported to achieve my personal and professional goals.
... Being supported to look after myself.
... Being supported if I needed to address any workplace conflict.
... Meaningful.
... Purposeful.
... Stimulating.
... Energising.
... Something I am proud of.
What is one thing that you have done well at work during the last 12 months that you are especially proud of?
Is it DIFFICULT to maintain a balance between the demands of your working life and the demands of your personal life?
... make balancing work/home EASIER?
... make balancing work/home MORE DIFFICULT?
Are you able to access flexible work practices in your workplace?
My manager is aware of and accommodates work/life balance issues.
My colleagues are flexible and supportive in helping me attend to work/life balance issues.
The organisation actively accommodates the work/life balance needs of employees.
Employees are able to access alternative working arrangements to accommodate work/life balance issues
On balance, is your organisation a “truly great place to work”?
If YES, what makes it a “truly great place to work”?
If NO, what is stopping it from becoming a “truly great place to work”?
... a good place to work
Why did you give this score?
... the best choice if they required the type of service we provide
Why did you give this score?
What initially attracted you to work in this organisation?
Why do you continue to work here?

Do you OFTEN think of leaving this organisation?
... to want to STAY working here?
... to want to STAY working here?
... to want to STAY working here?
... to want to LEAVE the organisation?
... to want to LEAVE the organisation?

Overall, how long do you intend to stay working for the organisation in the future?
The organisation is committed to real action on Diversity and Inclusion.
... Their cultural and/or linguistic background.
... Their gender.
... Their sexuality.
... Their age.
... Their faith or religion.
... Identifying as an Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander person.
... Identifying as a person with disability.
The organisation is a culturally inclusive employer.
In my workplace, other employees would be accepting and supportive of any employee who identified themselves as being an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person.
In my workplace, other employees would be accepting and supportive of any employee who identified themselves as being of Non-English speaking heritage/background.
The organisation provides a culturally safe workplace for staff of diverse cultural backgrounds.
My immediate supervisor/manager genuinely supports equality between women and men.
I have the flexibility I need to manage my work and my family or caring responsibilities.
In my organisation sex-based harassment is not tolerated.
In my organisation, women are provided with equal opportunity to work in management positions.
Has a strong, clear sense of vision and future direction.
Is innovative, progressive, pro-active and dynamic.
Is focused on performance, results, and achieving its goals.
Is striving to create change.
Is focused on meeting the needs of the clients it serves.
Has strong, effective teamwork.
Has good, effective internal communication.
Is flexible, adaptable and embraces change.
Has people who are competent and knowledgeable with good skill levels.
Is very effective at creating strong partnerships with other groups and organisations.
Has appropriate and effective internal processes, systems and procedures.
Has strong, effective collaboration across teams within the organisation.
Has a supportive internal environment.
Provides effective support services to its client-base.
Has an environment where staff feel valued, encouraged and appreciated.
What is one thing that your organisation does well that you are especially proud of?
The one thing that this organisation values above everything else, is TO …
Executive Management has clearly communicated the organisation’s strategic direction and priorities to all employees.
The decisions and policies of Executive Management are consistently focused on achieving the organisation’s strategic direction
Employees are very clear about the organisation’s strategic direction and priorities.
I understand what the current Strategic Plan means for my work.
I know where I can get more information about the current Strategic Plan.
Is achievable
Is going in the right direction
Will provide good opportunities for me

Respect
Honesty
Fairness
Equality
High ethical standards of behaviour
High quality standards of work
High quality standards of service to clients
High standards of accountability.
Each person has a clear understanding about what they are accountable and responsible for.
Any decisions they make are fair and equitable - they do not show favouritism or bias.
There is no inappropriate interference in recruitment, selection and promotion processes.
Any decisions they make about the use of resources are prudent and economical - they are not wasteful or extravagant.

Any usage of their computer access is for appropriate purposes - they do not download offensive material off the internet, make excessive personal use of emails, or make personal use of social networking sites in work time.
Each person that I work with is open and honest when reporting to senior staff.
Each person that I work with considers risks and takes appropriate action.
Each person that I work with makes decisions based on ethics and integrity.
Any actions they take are proper and legal - they would easily withstand external scrutiny.
Each person is prepared to speak up about misconduct or corrupt activity - they do not tolerate improper or unlawful behaviour
Know each other well.
Are quick to step in and help each other
Are clear about what other team members expect from them.
Have confidence and trust in the team leader.
Never leave the job half done.
Work to fix any mistakes - rather than cover them up.
I feel safe in discussing work problems with other team members.
I feel safe in discussing work problems with my team leader.
My team leader encourages me to find new ways of doing my job better.
I feel that any new ideas or changes I make are appreciated.
I feel a sense of pride when the changes I make in my job have good results.
... Press hard for better answers to long term problems.
... Seek innovative solutions to tough problems.
... Look for new and better ways of doing things.
... Speak up if they see a problem.

Is your workplace a safe place for you to work?
If NO, what are the things that make it unsafe for you personally?
Your co-workers.
Your manager.
Your workplace's Safety Representative.
Your organisation's Executive Management.
Your professional colleagues.
Report this safety problem.
Know how to go about reporting this safety problem.
Trust that, if this safety problem was reported, then it would be appropriately addressed.
Reporting workplace safety problems.
Addressing workplace safety problems.
Consulting staff prior to making changes that could affect workplace safety.
Workplace Safety is a priority for Management.
The organisation is getting better at fixing Workplace Safety problems.
The organisation has high standards of Workplace Safety because it has enough staff doing the work.
The organisation has high standards of Workplace Safety because it makes sure that staff are competent.
Workplace Safety is included in the organisation’s orientation and development programs for all staff.
The organisation monitors Workplace Safety all the time.
The organisation is very open about dealing with Workplace Safety problems.
The organisation fixes Workplace Safety risks quickly.
Internal Workplace Safety investigations focus on fixing things... not on judging people.
Clients.
Friends and relatives of clients.

Think of your manager, the person you primarily report to, who is responsible for conducting your performance review.
What are the 3 words or phrases you would use to describe the leadership style of this person?
What are the 3 words or phrases you would use to describe the leadership style of this person?
What are the 3 words or phrases you would use to describe the leadership style of this person?
Trustworthy
Friendly
Motivated
Hardworking
Professional
Competent
Fair
Inclusive
Decisive
Consistent
Flexible
Proactive
Visionary
A Role Model (leading by example)
Good communicators
Inspirational
Supportive
Approachable
Encouraging
Empowering
Understanding
Helpful
A good Team-Builder
A good Listener
Accessible
Responsive
1 What are the 3 most important things that you expect from this person?
2 What are the 3 most important things that you expect from this person?
3 What are the 3 most important things that you expect from this person?
1 How much do you agree that your manager consistently meets your expectations?
2 How much do you agree that your manager consistently meets your expectations?
3 How much do you agree that your manager consistently meets your expectations?
What are the 3 most important things that this person expects from you?
What are the 3 most important things that this person expects from you?
What are the 3 most important things that this person expects from you?
Clearly communicates to you what they expect from you.
Measures how well you perform against these expectations.
Gives you constructive feedback on your performance.
Helps you to set realistic performance objectives.
Helps you to plan how to improve your performance.
Helps you to plan your personal/professional development.
Reviews your progress in achieving your objectives.
Conducts annual performance reviews with you.
Is a role model you look up to and learn from.
Provides reward and recognition for outstanding performance.
Provides appreciation for good performance.
Provides support and guidance to help overcome any performance shortfalls.
Is prepared to address poor performance in a constructive manner.
Has set the standards for building a great team - they will settle for nothing less.
Has an unwavering resolve to do whatever it takes to produce the best long term results - no matter how big or hard the decisions.
Has a quiet, self-effacing, modest style - they are never boastful or arrogant.
Displays a constant diligence to continually find a better way to do things.
Is tough - but fair.
Leads the team well.
Communicates a very clear vision and direction for where they want the team to go.
Creates a strong sense of team cohesion and purpose.
Puts an extraordinary amount of time and attention into getting the right team members in the right jobs.
Holds team members accountable for what they should be doing.
Acts decisively in moving/removing team members who are not performing.
Recognises and rewards great performance by team members.
Communicates well on a one-to-one basis.
Listens well on a one-to-one basis.
Considers the views and opinions of others.
Knows when to say ‘no’ - and does so!
Encourages robust debate amongst the team as a way of reaching the best decisions for the team.
Always wants to hear the truth - regardless of how uncomfortable it may be.
When faced with adversity, this person will make a determined effort to expose, and face up to, the brutal facts of the situation.
Regardless of how difficult the situation, this person always exudes a sense of confidence that we will get through it.
If there was one message you would like to pass on to the most senior executive in this organisation

Was this a BPA employee survey?
From the organisation?
From your manager?
Accurate (it was a truthful and balanced picture of the organisation).
Timely (it was delivered within a short time after the survey).
Action oriented (it set out a clear plan of action for the future).

I broadly understand the challenges that the organisation will experience over the next 12-18 months.
I am confident that the changes that the organisation introduces will be well planned, well thought-out and client focused.
I have a good understanding of how these changes will affect me in my work area.
I am confident that I’ll be well communicated with about these changes when information is at hand.
Me personally
My work area
The organisation’s clients
The organisation itself
The community in general
I am confident that if these changes produce any unintended consequences, then the organisation will be fast and flexible
I am confident in my own ability to respond well to this environment of constant change in how we do things.
... the thing you are most excited about?
... the thing you are most concerned about?
The organisation introduces change quickly. It is fast, focused and flexible.
In the last 1 to 2 years, the organisation has made significant improvements.
What is one thing that has improved in your working environment during the past year?
What is one thing that has deteriorated in your working environment during the past year?
The organisation wants to hear the bad news as well as the good news about itself.
The organisation acts quickly to stop small problems becoming large problems.
My manager wants to hear the bad news as well as the good news.
My manager acts quickly to stop small problems becoming large problems.
Communication in the organisation
Motivation in the organisation
The organisation’s services and facilities
The organisation’s client satisfaction levels
Communication regarding the previous employee survey’s results was open and honest.
We are positive about the changes that have occurred in the last few months.
We are continuing to improve our processes and the way we do our work.
People are committed to improving the way we do things in the organisation.
Communication from Executive Management is providing a sense of purpose and direction.
We recognise our achievements - staff are acknowledged for their work and the contributions they make.
We celebrate our successes.
We are trying to maintain a positive work environment.
We put into practice our organisational values.
Executive Management is supportive in this time of change.
My manager is supportive in this time of change.
My manager has the skills and capability to support me in this time of change.
Unacceptable behaviour is being responded to and dealt with.
We are breaking down the silos and working more effectively with our colleagues.
Team work is being encouraged.
We are well prepared for the changes ahead.
... What is 1 thing that we should NOT change?
... What is 1 thing that we should do a little LESS of?
... What is 1 thing that we should do a little MORE of?

Executive Management is committed to providing quality service to clients.
Executive Management wants to know feedback from clients.
This organisation has specifically defined what exceptional service is.
Employees understand exactly what they must do to deliver exceptional service.
Staffing levels are adequate to meet client needs.
Employees meet the clients’ expectations on delivering exceptional service.
This organisation prides itself on providing service that is “right the first time”.
The client records completed by employees are totally error-free.
What is one thing that currently frustrates clients the most in their experiences with the organisation?

People in my work unit are highly conscious of the potential for adverse patient safety events.
People in my work unit report adverse patient safety events and complaints quickly and openly.
People in my work unit treat patient safety events as learning opportunities.
People in my work unit always follow evidence, guidelines, standards, procedures, and pathways
People in my work unit exercise good judgement about when to escalate a deterioration in a patient’s condition.
People in my work unit will persevere in escalating concerns when they believe it’s clinically appropriate.
... Press hard for better answers to long term patient safety and quality of care problems.
... Seek innovative solutions to recurring patient safety and quality of care problems.
... Learn from the experience of others outside the work unit to improve patient safety and quality of care.
... Look for new and better ways of managing patient safety and quality of care.
... Speak up if they see a patient safety or quality of care problem.
... Implement solutions to any patient safety or quality of care problems identified.
... Close the loop by checking that solutions implemented fixed the problem for the patient.
